message.content:
A merism is a figure of speech in which a whole is described by mentioning only its parts or vice versa. It involves the use of hyperbole to emphasize an idea, often by dividing it into two equal parts and describing each part separately. Merisms are commonly used in poetry, literature, and everyday language.

For example, if someone says "I'm over the moon," they mean they are extremely happy. In this case, the whole concept of happiness is described by mentioning only a part of it (the moon). Another example is when someone describes someone as being "head to toe" attractive, meaning that their attractiveness extends from head to toe.

Merisms can also be used to describe a complete absence or lack of something. For instance, if someone says they are "at the end of their tether," it means they have reached the limit of their patience and are extremely frustrated. In this case, the whole concept of frustration is described by mentioning only one part of it (the end of a rope).

Merisms can be quite poetic and evocative, as they create vivid mental images and help to emphasize the point being made.
